title_review: Well worth the trip from Madrid..ESTUPENDO!
review_preview: We first discovered Bahia Taberna during a forced overnight layover at Barajas and decided we had to return on our next visit to Madrid, it is that good! When our friends in Madrid asked where we were dining and we said Barajas the immediate response...
review_full: We first discovered Bahia Taberna during a forced overnight layover at Barajas and decided we had to return on our next visit to Madrid, it is that good! When our friends in Madrid asked where we were dining and we said Barajas the immediate response was .. Pero Porque? We took the direct 5 metro from Madrid Centro to Alameda de Osuna, about 20 minutes. Although there is a bus connection to Calle Bahia de Palma we opted for the short cab ride to the restaurant and also back to the metro stop. Having enjoyed hors oeuvres and an aperitif with friends prior to our meal we opted to start with the four step menu instead of the eight step we so enjoyed on our last visit. The icy cold cava was beautifully dry and elegant to start and we chose the wine pairing as well for our meal. Our meal was as satisfying to the eye and the palate as on last visit, always inventive and wonderfully fresh. We had cauliflower in a mayonnaise sauce topped with red and black caviar that was cool and sumptuous as a first course, followed by a deliciously tender and succulent filleted sardine tartare, next an inventive and surprising take on ossobuco and finished with their rabo de toro interpretation which we so enjoyed before. All dishes were beautifully paired with wines from Spain, the white from La Mancha was simply spectacular. After all that cava and wine we can't recollect what was had for dessert, just know that it was good! Barajas is a lovely town and not just and airport, and Bahia Taberna is certainly worth the short metro journey from Madrid

review_full: I agree with the other reviewers that this is an amazing place to eat. From the outside it appears to be just another corner restaurant and from the limited menu choices you might think you made a mistake in coming here. WRONG. The food is presented in a manner consistent with multi-star establishments and the quality is excellent. I had their daily special which was a choice of 3 tapas, an appetizer, bread, desert and drink for 15 euros. The waitress was very helpful in explaining the menu choices and seemed proud to explain the ingredients of each dish she served. I wish I could have eaten there again but was only in town for 1 evening. Please note the location listed for Bahia is wrong. See YaYa1942's post for correct address.

review_preview: La Taverna Bahia is located on Calle Bahia de Palma, not on Calle de Santender--not far, but if you're walking along Calle de Santender looking for the restaurant, you won't find it.When you get to La Bahia, however, prepare for a first class dining...
review_full: La Taverna Bahia is located on Calle Bahia de Palma, not on Calle de Santender--not far, but if you're walking along Calle de Santender looking for the restaurant, you won't find it. When you get to La Bahia, however, prepare for a first class dining experience. Creative variations on Spanish classics are elegantly presented. We had some fine meals of essential Spanish fare throughout southern Spain, but for first-class cuisine that remains within the Spanish tradition, nothing previous came close to La Bahia. If you're anywhere near Barajas airport in Madrid for a meal don't miss La Bahia.

title_review: Best tapas I had in Seville and Madrid and reasonably priced
review_preview: I love hole-in-the-wall, unassuming restaurants.  Bahia Taberna is one of them.  If you're staying at the Hilton Madrid Airport, then this is a perfect place to dine, located just 5 min away from the hotel.  You would never guess the magnitude of the culinary experience...
review_full: I love hole-in-the-wall, unassuming restaurants. Bahia Taberna is one of them. If you're staying at the Hilton Madrid Airport, then this is a perfect place to dine, located just 5 min away from the hotel. You would never guess the magnitude of the culinary experience from its suburban location. We dined at the low tables had the 6 course + amuse + extra dessert tasting menu for 39 EUR, a bargain!. The long menu adds an additional main course for 9 EUR more. I made a reservation a few months in advance, but it was not crowded when I visited on a weeknight. In the future, I would dine at the high tables, where I can order more freely off the menu. The low tables are restricted to the tasting menus only. The wait staff were very good and spoke very good English, bringing free bread refills too! In a few words; spectacular, playful, delicious. I'll let my pictures do the talking. If I had one critique, I would say that maybe there was too much use of mayonnaise (as delicious as it was)?

title_review: Tapas turned into a dining experience
review_preview: I booked this tapas restaurant based on the positive opinions and due to the proximity with the hotel were I was staying and I must say that I was pleasantly surprised despite the high expectations..Food was terrific with very innovative "high-end tapas"  with fresh...
review_full: I booked this tapas restaurant based on the positive opinions and due to the proximity with the hotel were I was staying and I must say that I was pleasantly surprised despite the high expectations.. Food was terrific with very innovative "high-end tapas" with fresh ingredients and always well presented. I cannot recommend anything in particular as they all tasted great to me...perhaps the specialty of the restaurant, the "pizza de chipirones" was outstanding. review_preview: Recently, we were overnighting in Madrid, staying near the airport (Hotel Maydrit), and decided to take a taxi (12 Eu for the 6 of us) to this neighborhood spot. We had the small (4-course) tasting menu, which included 2 appetizers, 4 main courses, 2 desserts,...
review_full: Recently, we were overnighting in Madrid, staying near the airport (Hotel Maydrit), and decided to take a taxi (12 Eu for the 6 of us) to this neighborhood spot. We had the small (4-course) tasting menu, which included 2 appetizers, 4 main courses, 2 desserts, and finally a selection of sweets. Without exception, all were incredibly tasty, and we could not begin to finish all the food. Even though the courses were small, the total number finally overwhelmed our gastric capacity, and we threw in the towel. This fine meal was not cheap at $38 Eu/pp, but since it truly was memorable, we all felt it offered very good value considering the incredible food. Hint: do not fill up on the homemade breads, save space for the lamb, scallops, whitefish, squid, choccolates, etc.

You have the option to tell them anything you don't like or any food restrictions but after that you get what you get. You get a few appetisers to start with and then your main courses and desserts. Every dish was made up and we didn't see any other customer get the same as we got. Every dish was extremely good, the tastes and combinations were perfect and the desserts were amazing for taste. This is a place I will definitely be visiting again

The starter is fried cheese with jam, which's good but it could be found in many other restaurants. The main course is fish with potato, sort of tasteless. I think the speciality is related to pork. It is better to order that if you do eat meat. The dessert I chose something related to cream... so-so... A free drink (I chose sparkling water) and bread are included. The bread is surprisingly good indeed. The environment is quite tranquil and the staff is helpful, though.

review_preview: My wife and I had to spend a night at a hotel near by the airport to catch an early flight the next morning. So we turned to tripadviser for help to make the most out of our staying. What a lucky find for us!...
review_full: My wife and I had to spend a night at a hotel near by the airport to catch an early flight the next morning. So we turned to tripadviser for help to make the most out of our staying.  What a lucky find for us! It turned out to be the best meal we had in Spain. (This is the last of our 9-day trip in Spain) Absolutely Michelin quality but with down to earth approach. We started with the "small" menu and changed to the "big" menu midway through, not because it wasn't enough food. It's so good, we wanted to try more. The staffs were very friendly. The head chef talked to us before and during the meal to make sure things are to our liking, the manager called taxi for us afterwards. The wine paring was fantastic too.  I would come back to Madrid or try to transfer flight in Madrid next time just for Bahia Taberna. It's that seriously good!!!

title_review: A fantastic meal very convenient for the airport
review_preview: I chose this place from reviews on Trip Advisor and for its proximity to the airport,  I was in a car but it would not be a big taxi ride to or from Madrid airport.Parking was relatively easy.  The entrance was a sort of...
review_full: I chose this place from reviews on Trip Advisor and for its proximity to the airport, I was in a car but it would not be a big taxi ride to or from Madrid airport. Parking was relatively easy. The entrance was a sort of bar area and I wondered if I had the right place. There is a small dining area at the back and they found me a table without difficulty. I asked for a menu but I was told that they would choose for me and did I have any allergies or dislikes.  With only a little trepidation, I accepted this and was then served with dish after dish of interesting and exciting food. I will certainly return on my next visit to Madrid.

review_preview: We picked this restaurant because of the nice reviews it has and the pretty photos that diners have posted. If you are looking for sophisticated fine dining, this is not the place. But then one should know beforehand as the name 'Taberna' implies. We were...
review_full: We picked this restaurant because of the nice reviews it has and the pretty photos that diners have posted. If you are looking for sophisticated fine dining, this is not the place. But then one should know beforehand as the name 'Taberna' implies. We were being seated at the high tables, and only after much clarification that we will be having the tasting menu (most staff speaks minimal English) that we were directed to the main restaurant with clothed tables. I find it strange that while they serve a tasting menu, they don't understand the concept of wine pairing... The dishes were all prettily and artfully presented, but come to think of it, they are mostly pub food in essence: cucumber and beans pate; squid tempura; garden peas, pea shoots, pea pur√©e n Burrata... The squid tomato bruschetta must have been their signature dish. It was brilliant, but still, it was just a Burrata. Deep fried Chicken wings and soft shell crabs...followed by fish tartar! Seriously? Braised Oxtail was delicious, but 3 big pieces for a tasting menu was a bit over generous. The weakest link however was in the desserts, which ended up lame and anticlimactic. I suppose it is a nice choice if you just want a nice dinner nearby, but it is definitely not worth a trip from the city centre. And be warned, it is basically pub food.

We really loved our meal and hopefully we will return in the future.

review_preview: One of the best Japanese meals I've ever had. Extraordinary food, amazing service (gracias, Camilo!). We let our waiter choose all our food and everything was simply outstanding. Will so be going back. Just a note in response to some reviews complaining about this place...
review_full: One of the best Japanese meals I've ever had. Extraordinary food, amazing service (gracias, Camilo!). We let our waiter choose all our food and everything was simply outstanding. Will so be going back.  Just a note in response to some reviews complaining about this place not selling sushi or sashimi. That comment is as short-sighted as someone complaining about a Spanish restaurant not selling tortilla espa√±ola. There is so much more to Japanese cuisine than sushi and sashimi, like there is so much more to Spanish cuisine than Spanish omelette. Some places will sell it, some won't, but that is in no way a factor to rate a restaurant. If you want sushi, go to a sushi bar. If you want outstanding, authentic Japanese food, go to Torikey.

I found the food to be executed very well, minimum of one star perhaps flirting with two. The service was fine, but not to Michelin standards, got up to go to the WC, came back, napkin still in chair. Sometimes the pairings were served before the course, sometimes afterwards, little details. That all being said, was our best meal thus far in Madrid. I also thought it was a good value for what you are getting. This is fine dinning and not cheap, but relative to some of the one stars we ate at. Happily would eat here again.

review_preview: A short walk from our hotel off of Retiro Park, this was a great experience. Located in a very upscale area, but nice and cosy... I knew we were in for something special when, just after we were seated, our server brought us 2 perfect...
review_full: A short walk from our hotel off of Retiro Park, this was a great experience. Located in a very upscale area, but nice and cosy...  I knew we were in for something special when, just after we were seated, our server brought us 2 perfect looking cherries with stems on a white plate. Alright, let's go with it... we popped them in and realized they were not cherries, but unbelievably delicious balls of fois gras made to look like cherries. Wow. We selected this place because the specialized in raw tuna dishes, and those were indeed spectacular, but everything was great. A must have, and you're going to have to trust me on this, is what can only be called a slab of tomato. You'll see photos scattered through the gallery... Giant tomato slice, a touch of olive oil, and this amazing shaved sea salt (you'll find it everywhere) - That's it, and it so works. We also had the wild mushroom cannoli - also amazing, and then 2 different raw tuna dishes. They were both delicious, but a little similar, and if I were doing it again, I would diversify on the entrees. But that's on me. The fixed price menu was about $37, which was pretty reasonable for what we got, Throw in a $35 bottle of Rioja and it's a happy, happy night.  This is definitely going on the revisit list.

It is difficult though to find restaurants that remove this part of the shrimp.

review_full: We were recommended the restaurant by a girlfriend of my old Spanish teacher AND it is open on Sunday. We reserved a week before and they were expecting us (I suspect we need not have because few people eat out on Sunday evening). We ordered a couples of ca√±as and the menu. Having looked through it I got a feeling that they would look after us come what may. I simply said no red meat but chicken is OK and fish is OK. You bought it - you cooked it so you choose it. Starters mains and the only thing I'd say is we like red wine over white whether it's fish or fowl. The starters arrived and were delicious. The main courses arrived and were exceptional (especially for the money). We were advised to have a wine NOT on the menu because it was both better and cheaper than the Ribera del Duero on the card. They only had one portion of lemon pudding (a sort of English type of Lemon meringue pie. It was large and we shared. The bill was 61‚Ç¨ for the 2 of us and that wouldn't get you one starter in a Michelin restaurant in Paris. Have no hesitation in going ........ and they're a nice bunch too.

review_preview: I wasn't quite sure what to expect when we turned up at Che Pibil. It was a Saturday night and the place was pretty quiet (though Madrid tends to be quiet in August). It doesn't look like much from the outside: more front-room-made-restaurant than anything...
review_full: I wasn't quite sure what to expect when we turned up at Che Pibil. It was a Saturday night and the place was pretty quiet (though Madrid tends to be quiet in August). It doesn't look like much from the outside: more front-room-made-restaurant than anything else.  But I'd read good things, and appearance isn't everything.  The food was...amazing. Empanadas were really flavoursome, and the burrata was beautiful. Highly recommend both.  Then, what we came for, the Argentinian meats. Didn't disappoint, as we'd pigged out on the starters, we didn't end up going for the larger sharing cuts, so among the four of us we ordered the entra√±a, vacio, entrecot and lomo Argentino especialidad de la casa. The entra√±a was exquisite, the lomo too. They were all cooked perfectly and we're obviously a good quality. Ranging between 17-22‚Ç¨, good value for the area too.  Can't go wrong with dulce de leche for postre either!!  The service was very fast and very friendly, this was probably my favourite thing and considering how much I enjoyed the food, that says something. It felt very homely.  I'd say the only thing that let it down was the strange pricing of the drinks: 17‚Ç¨ for a supermarket wine (Cune) and 6‚Ç¨ for a bottle of still water took away from the charming aspect of everything else, I'd pay more for the meat without complaining because it's worth it...but don't charge 6‚Ç¨ for water!

title_review: Amazing food in a place you would not expect
review_preview: I have been living for 5 years in Argentina and am going to take the freedom to say that this is one of the best Argentine restaurants I have tried to date in Madrid. Unlike restaurants that look expensive are expensive and where you expect...
review_full: I have been living for 5 years in Argentina and am going to take the freedom to say that this is one of the best Argentine restaurants I have tried to date in Madrid. Unlike restaurants that look expensive are expensive and where you expect the food to taste amazing but are ultimately disappointed, this place from the outside is easy to miss and does not necessarily look like a restaurant but don't get fooled by the looks. The food is delicious. The starters are amazing. We had the chorizo, provoletta and buratta as starters. One was better than the other. The chorizo comes with chimichurri that is one of the best recipes I have tried in Madrid. I love chimichurri and have high expectations to it. The owner explained that the recipe is from her grandfather and a family sauce. For the main dish we had the ojo de lomo argentino that comes already sliced. Delicious. The owners are from Argentina and the cook is from Uruguay so you cannot go wrong with this restaurant. Now it's not the place to bring your first date. However if you are looking at celebrating Argentine food then this is the place to go.

review_preview: First of all, this is a little deli shop in the basement of the Mercado of Chamartin (so you can't see it from the road. Tables are arranged opposite the shop and the set menu changes every day, but standard pasta (full or half portion)...
review_full: First of all, this is a little deli shop in the basement of the Mercado of Chamartin (so you can't see it from the road.  Tables are arranged opposite the shop and the set menu changes every day, but standard pasta (full or half portion) is available as well. I went for a half portion of porcini&truffle oil tagliatelle and half of lasagne. The former were a little overcooked and definitely floating in too much oil; lasagne were ok even though a cheap type of cheese (not mozzarella) was used. Prices are ok but not particularly cheap (apart from the good set menu deal that includes primo and secondo). I expected a bit more but the staff is attentive despite the usual business of the shop.

title_review: Old-fashioned and entertaining with well-executed food
review_preview: It's been a while since I've eaten at this sort of old-fashioned high-end restaurant, where there is an enforced dress code for men and where the waiters still help prepare the food.Having read some previous reviews, I was rather dreading it since we usually...
review_full: It's been a while since I've eaten at this sort of old-fashioned high-end restaurant, where there is an enforced dress code for men and where the waiters still help prepare the food. Having read some previous reviews, I was rather dreading it since we usually go to Michelin-starred restaurants in whatever gear we have on and the whole place sounded too formal. But really, the jacket and tie business is simply arranged - they warn you on the phone when you make the reservation and when you arrive, you are whisked away to a cloakroom where a nice lady efficiently kits you out. We had dinner on a Friday night - the place was packed, apparently mostly with Spanish patrons. Tables are nicely-spaced out, comfortable seats, a warm rich decor. We had the tasting menu which is around Euros 100 per person, with very generous-sized portions for each course so you need to be hungry. The menu was a strange dichotomy : more modern dishes to start and more traditional dishes as you progressed. Lots of sauces which I found a little heavy. The (mostly older) waiters are involved in cooking, plating, flambeeing etc., which is always entertaining to watch and at which they are very skilled. The dishes in the tasting menu were well-executed, with the exception of a venison dish where the meat was a thin overcooked medallion, in a sickly sauce which wasn't doing anyone any favours. Looking at the other tables, steak tartare and seafood/lobster salad seemed to be extremely popular. The wine list is extensive and very reasonably-priced. Service was attentive but occasionally too brisk. My husband's plate was whipped away when he hadn't yet finished and we barely had time to sample the tapas/canapes before they too were whipped away as our first courses arrived. But the waiters and sommelier were friendly enough - it's certainly not stuffy or formal and what I would expect from fine dining. While we prefer more modern-style cooking and dining, sometimes it's good to go to a traditional place like this for a change. The restaurant has obviously maintained its high standard and popularity over decades which is impressive. Besides...how often can you say that you've eaten at the same restaurant as the King and Queen of Spain?(!!)

Nothing wrong with this but We also seek a fun ambiance too. But definitely a must must go for those that are serious about their food, wine and service. Enjoy.

title_review: Very elegant, formal restaurnt with excelent cuisine.
review_preview: This was for years considered the finest restaurant in Madrid if not the country. It is very formal with jacket and tie required. This is a HUGE plus, because there are few places in Madrid to dress up to celebrate in. We had been here...
review_full: This was for years considered the finest restaurant in Madrid if not the country. It is very formal with jacket and tie required. This is a HUGE plus, because there are few places in Madrid to dress up to celebrate in. We had been here a few years ago and wanted to return, I am glad we did. The food is more formal Spanish, with the steaks being standouts as well as the house made desserts. A huge and very fine wine list from all over the world, but particularly from Spain!! the staff is wonderfully attentive and professional. there are few servers like this left in the world. If you like elegant, very quiet formal dinning where you can actually talk to your companion, Zalacain is a must!

review_preview: I don't understand the previous negative reviews, especially on service.  This is "classic" Spanish not trying to compete with Foam, and molecular gastronomy restaurants.  The decor is older, the service is formal, the dress code is enforced.  We were one of only two American tables,...
review_full: I don't understand the previous negative reviews, especially on service. This is "classic" Spanish not trying to compete with Foam, and molecular gastronomy restaurants. The decor is older, the service is formal, the dress code is enforced. We were one of only two American tables, and received incredible service throughout. The staff answered questions, smiled, laughed and were very engaged throughout. Food was absolutely delicious. We ordered a la carte and told them we would be sharing. Each dish was plated separately in the kitchen and served as if it were a tasting menu, one after the other. Foie Gras, crunchy shrimp, pasta with runny egg, sea bass, and steak tartare with potato. Larger portions than expected and all excellent. Huge wine list with a great sommelier. Expensive, but most Michelin 2 stars are. This was worth every Euro.

review_full: I had read a review elsewhere of Casa Lucas and decided it would be my lunchtime destination one afternoon. The pinchos (snacks) menu is small, but exciting. I only glanced at the main menu as I thought it was overpriced, as were the pinchos, but not as bad everything else. In short, the food I had was superb. I ordered 2 different pinchos, which are similar to bruschetta in that they come on crusty bread. 2 was almost enough for a full meal, though I was still a little hungry afterward. One was soy sauce marinated chicken with caramelized onions and corn mousse and a sesame oil drizzle. The saltiness of the chicken was beautiful with the smooth, sweet-ish mousse and onions. The second pincho was ratatouille topped with a perfectly-fried quail egg and a little crispy ham. Also heavenly. Definitely stop in here to fuel yourself with snacks if you've been to the Palacio Real or San Francisco Basilica.

title_review: Warm hospitality, superb food in a small, centrally located place
review_preview: We ate Casa Lucas on four or five nights out of 8 in Madrid. Close to Plaza Mayor, it is obviously a favorite with locals and tourists; highly rated by several guides. The three "front" staff were the most hospitable we have seen anywhere. Little...
review_full: We ate Casa Lucas on four or five nights out of 8 in Madrid. Close to Plaza Mayor, it is obviously a favorite with locals and tourists; highly rated by several guides. The three "front" staff were the most hospitable we have seen anywhere. Little or no English, but doesn't matter. Typical tapas and drinks, prices comparable to other places, but it felt genuine. Squid with ink the best ever; also eggs and other typical tapas. It opens at 20:00. Go by 20:40 to get a seat at this small gem. It will make you feel good. Don't take cars to this street.

title_review: Left feeling totally underwhelmed...billed as the best paella...definitely isn't.
review_preview: We ate at the sister restaurant across the street and chose to go to the Marina Ventura on our last night in Madrid. We arrived early as we had a morning flight and were the first table to be seated. We were seated at a...
review_full: We ate at the sister restaurant across the street and chose to go to the Marina Ventura on our last night in Madrid.  We arrived early as we had a morning flight and were the first table to be seated. We were seated at a table where the paint had started to peel off the wall. The decor is a bit confusing, a mix of old wooden beams that could be a great feature, combined with loud colours on the wall of alternating turquoise and green.  We ordered some shellfish starters and a seafood paella, after all it's a seafood restaurant. The seafood paella was beautifully presented, with crabs, lobsters, prawns etc. on display. The problem is that we wanted a meal that we could eat as well as admire. There was virtually no substance to the various decorative sealife and it was a major effort to get anything out of the shells as they were so small. Rice was average. Nothing to write home about.  Didn't bother with dessert. Rice was very filling and despite having a couple of tables to look after in the section, the 2 staff were having a coffee and/or put of sight.  I would suggest either another seafood restaurant or the Argentinian steak restaurant opposite.

review_preview: I first went to Zalacain in the late Eighties when this restaurant was a Michelin 3 star. The only one in Spain. It lost 2 stars in 1995 and has never gained them back.I thought at the time that Zalacain was highly overrated and...
review_full: I first went to Zalacain in the late Eighties when this restaurant was a Michelin 3 star. The only one in Spain. It lost 2 stars in 1995 and has never gained them back. I thought at the time that Zalacain was highly overrated and Michelin finally agreed. The restaurant is quite attractive, but it lacks that din, or buzz of energy, of the greatest restaurants. The service is slightly haughty and perfunctory, but polished. Let's look at the menu. They offer a couple of different Prix Fixe menu's at ‚Ç¨99/person and ‚Ç¨105/person. Al la carte, for me starts with Ravioli stuffed with wild mushrooms and fresh goose-liver with ‚ÄúMelanosportum‚Äù truffle, or  Prawns macerated with avocado and orange salad, or Terrine of fresh goose-liver with marmalade and pur√©e of apple. For main's, I suggest the Grilled Fresh Goose Liver with Pedro Ximenez Sauce and dried peach, or Wild Mushrooms and Fresh Goose Liver Lasagne, or Sirloin with Wild Mushroom Sauce and fresh goose liver. Dessert? Very pretty: meringue cake with violet‚Äôs ice-cream, or almond roof-tile and mignardises. Figure to spend ‚Ç¨100-‚Ç¨125/person without drinks and wine. The wine list is comprehensive and over priced. DiverXO, the latest, and only existing 3 star restaurant in Madrid, is vastly superior.  As are the two-star Santceloni and La Terraza del Casino. As well as, Sergi Arola, El Club Allard and Ramon Freixa Madrid.

review_preview: Sometimes you have to pay for your pleasure and a meal at Zalacain falls in to that category. I was drawn to this establishment like a moth to a flame. I knew all about its stiff and stuffy dress code - one is reminded whilst...
review_full: Sometimes you have to pay for your pleasure and a meal at Zalacain falls in to that category. I was drawn to this establishment like a moth to a flame. I knew all about its stiff and stuffy dress code - one is reminded whilst booking "that a gentlemen wears a jacket and tie." I was even aware of its recently lost Michelin star. However, its overly conservative and traditional style as well as a menu I can understand meant that wanted to give it a go.  Okay, my wife and I turn up and gulp at the prices at the entrance. One deep breath and we enter. It's a warm welcome and I'm aware that we've passed Zalacain's grooming criteria. I have to say that from that moment on we were treated with the utmost courtesy and exemplary professionalism. You should expect that from a place like this but staff were also warm and friendly too.  Aided by a first class sommelier I choose a bottle of wine from a huge wine list. This is the cue for the arrival of some pre starter amuse bouche and tasty nibbles. Be warned, you will be charged for anything that is placed on the table - nothing is free, including the miniature bread rolls you don't eat. My wife starts with partridge and I go for the ravioli. Both are tasty in a traditional sense but lack the excitement and drama I want in a top establishment. For my main I opt for a Zalacain classic, the lobster salad. It's delicious fresh lobster on a bed of ordinary lettuce and way too much creamy dressing. I can't give the chef any kind of compliment. My wife opts for goose liver (it's not foie gras) with pedro ximenez and it gets a firm thumbs up. We finish with fresh seasonal raspberries. Our fellow guests consist of a couple of business men that look as though they eat here regularly; an older Madridleno couple and ghastly table of ten straight out of casting for Madrid Wives. I'm left with the impression that Zalacain is as much a social club for the conservative wealth of Madrid as much as restaurant. Despite the excellent service I get a feeling that they are going through the motions. The food lacked flair and I'm not surprised they lost the Michelin star. It's not cheap, far from it, but I would say do it once for experience. It's too expensive for top marks but despite all my reservations we had an enjoyable and memorable meal.

title_review: Excellent but very formal restaurant with some menu quirks
review_preview: We came here for an anniversary meal.  It was the most formal restaurant experience I have had in a long time, with jacket and tie obligatory for the gentlemen, but it is nice to dress up sometimes.  Service was attentive to the point of being...
review_full: We came here for an anniversary meal. It was the most formal restaurant experience I have had in a long time, with jacket and tie obligatory for the gentlemen, but it is nice to dress up sometimes. Service was attentive to the point of being overbearing when we arrived at 9pm as the first customers but remained excellent as the restaurant filled up. Good bread and starters as you would expect from a Michelin starred restaurant. Our starters were excellent, I really enjoyed my mackerel salad but was envious of my wife's ravioli which were phenomenal. My main was quirky as port trotters stuffed with lamb in a mustard source made for an odd combination of meat flavours but pleasant enough, bizarrely served with tempura style vegetables. Desserts all good. The weighty wine list was comprehensive, with sommelier on hand to advise, and excellent value (as commonly the case in Spain) for those of us used to UK restaurant mark ups on wine. All in all a highly enjoyable evening if you are happy with the extremely formal atmosphere.

title_review: Top notch service, great food and wine selection.  All the luxury without being too pretentious!
review_preview: Every trip we go on we always have one grand dinner because why not, we're on vacation and while in Madrid, Zalacain was our pick.  Although Zalacain is no longer a Michelin restaurant, the service is on point and the dishes are delicious, not to...
review_full: Every trip we go on we always have one grand dinner because why not, we're on vacation and while in Madrid, Zalacain was our pick. Although Zalacain is no longer a Michelin restaurant, the service is on point and the dishes are delicious, not to mention they have hosted the Spanish King and Queen. Want to feel like royalty? Zalacain is the place!  Located in the beautiful neighborhood, you are sure to be met by valet and escorted into the restaurant where, if you are lucky, the owner and his wife will take your coats, seat you at your table and given the menu. Both husband and wife are very warm and personable, make great conversation and recommend some great dishes on the menu. To start, they offer complementary tapas because this is the Spanish way and I am not complaining one bit. Croquets and meats yum! Champagne and wine to celebrate. I ordered a half a dozen of oysters on the half shell to start off with. Oysters were plump and fresh and delicious. My main course, I chose Entrecote de buey al vino tinto con tuetano de ternera joven (beef steak in red wine sauce with young veal bone marrow on top). My steak was perfectly rare for my liking, sauce was luxurious without overpowering the meat and the bone marrow topping took the dish to a whole new level. Wow! We also tried one of their "classic dishes" the mushroom and goose liver lasagna which was unlike any lasagna we've ever tasted. For Dessert, we enjoyed an assortment variety of pastries and chocolates which were delicate and delicious and a wonderful dessert wine I wish I remembered the name of. Service is white glove and TOP NOTCH! Food is aesthetically arranged and delicious. Fantastic wine selection and Spanish modern luxury without being too pretentious. Great place to dine while in Madrid!

title_review: High Class Service and Venue, limited Menu
review_preview: I took my family to this restaurant a few days ago. I give high marks to the restaurant serving staff (waiters) all were knowledgeable of the appropriate wine selections, with the various food combinations, and were most courteous and accommodating. It is primarily for this...
review_full: I took my family to this restaurant a few days ago. I give high marks to the restaurant serving staff (waiters) all were knowledgeable of the appropriate wine selections, with the various food combinations, and were most courteous and accommodating. It is primarily for this reason I give the restaurant 4/5. Also the ambiance of the restaurant was excellent, nicely decorated, especially the private rooms, though for the price I would have expected some traditional Spanish entertainment.  With reference to the food, I must confess that I've had far better, at lower cost. This restaurant is rightly placed in the top 10% of Madrid, and rightly not placed in the coveted top 1% of trip advisor. The food was good, but not great for the price paid, and the menu was very limited. There was 3 presentations which contained Goose liver, an ingredient over represented on the menu in comparison with its competitors in Madrid. The deserts did not impress me, and I give low marks for creativity. I left satisfied but not amazed.

title_review: Old school fine dining, Spanish style and great food
review_preview: This is really a unique experience, from what I could see it is a big old house which each room converted into a dining room. The service is quite formal but still manages to be warm and friendly. The sommelier was a master sommelier and...
review_full: This is really a unique experience, from what I could see it is a big old house which each room converted into a dining room. The service is quite formal but still manages to be warm and friendly. The sommelier was a master sommelier and when he spoke about wine, it sounded like poetry. He just came to us and said, what sort of wine would you like, and we described a few qualities of the wine, then he just thought about it for a minute and recommended one of the hundreds of wines that he knows. It was, of course, an excellent choice. Apart from the unique atmosphere, the food was absolutely great. Fortunately I did not pay for the meal, but I imagine it was quite expensive, so probably a place for a special occasion. But if you are just visiting Madrid and don't know when you'll come back, take the chance to visit here.

review_preview: A visit to aristocratic Spain.  Old school here means male patrons must wear a jacket and tie and the restaurant has only male wait staff. We had three dishes you won't find just anywhere: eel & leek cakes; black pudding topped with fresh orange colored...
review_full: A visit to aristocratic Spain. Old school here means male patrons must wear a jacket and tie and the restaurant has only male wait staff. We had three dishes you won't find just anywhere: eel & leek cakes; black pudding topped with fresh orange colored egg yolks and a trotter and lamb combination. The duck sausage and cheese plate were also excellent. Wine pairings were well done, particularly the dessert port. Ambiance is traditional and adult. Prices were reasonable for the type of place it is. Service was very attentive and we finished dinner in a very fast 90 minutes. Two nights earlier we had gone to Santeloni, a two-star creative mod-cuisine restaurant in a hotel nearby. Far better bang for the buck here, better service, and you actually know you are in Spain when you look around.

title_review: Affordable eating in a friendly atmosphere.
review_preview: Perhaps this recently opened restaurant (it's in it's first year) is in answer to La Cr√≠sis, because it serves welcome portions of well-prepared food at pocket-friendly prices. Los Porfiados has no pretentions to "fine dining" or "silver service". No. This is a straight forward meal...
review_full: Perhaps this recently opened restaurant (it's in it's first year) is in answer to La Cr√≠sis, because it serves welcome portions of well-prepared food at pocket-friendly prices. Los Porfiados has no pretentions to "fine dining" or "silver service". No. This is a straight forward meal service in a comfortable setting ‚Äî a bit like being invited into your best friend's Mum's kitchen. The setting is a reclaimed shop (or so it seems)*. Couches, armchairs and sofas are strewn around, with plenty of reading material. The open-plan kitchen sits off to the side and a few odd tables are placed near by. The menu changes frequently and is based on what is currently available in local markets. There's a distinct leaning towards dishes that originated in South America, but all is wholesome and well priced. Soups and salads; casseroles and empanadas; grills and fries, and plenty of fresh vegetables and fruit. As I wrote: wholesome. The drinks list is brief and basic. But it's there. Service is friendly, and generally helpful. Students like this place. So do couples...and families...and us older folks as well. We'll be back. * "Los Porfiados" means The Stubborn ‚Äî I understand this is in homage to the rear wall that resisted hours, many hours, of valiant attempts to renovate its surface. The colourful remains are, for me, a work of art in itself.

review_preview: We ate at Casa Lucas twice during our stay in Madrid. It is absolutely delicious and the staff is so kind and welcoming. My son‚Äôs name is Lucas and they gifted him a glass with Casa Lucas etched on. On our second visit they remembered...

My son‚Äôs name is Lucas and they gifted him a glass with Casa Lucas etched on. On our second visit they remembered exactly what we liked and greeted us warmly. I loved the rice dish with foie and eggs. So rich but so yummy! The tomato salad with goat cheese is also wonderful. My husband had the calamari and a few other tapas. All wonderful. My sons loved the tuna tataki and croquetas. We will definitely visit on our return to Madrid. An incredible experience overall - one we will remember fondly!

review_full: We loved this restaurant which was on a terrific street of food options. The goat cheese salad was delicious to share. I had always watched my husband enjoy squid with black ink but was not brave enough to try it.  This time the calamari was cut up in front of my eyes and there was a small dollop of greenish sauce which- surprise- when spread through the fish, became black ink. It was magic! AND my verdict is .....drum roll.... I loved it! I would return and do it all over again thanks to this great experience. And the service was excellent too with friendly staff and big smiles.

They also have a nice selections of beers, I tried Cibeles. I am not usually too enthusiastic about desserts but the Milhojas de Dulce de Leche was delicious. Oh, by the way, they have ILLY coffe, which is always a plus. The price was pretty reasonable, around 15‚Ç¨ a person. If you are planing to roam the Ant√≥n Mart√≠n / Huertas / Lavapi√©s area, it¬¥s well worth a visit, even for a quick piece of cake in the afternoon. title_review: If only the food were as good...
review_preview: I know I may get brickbats for this review, but you can only judge by your own experience, and this was ours.Los Porfiados has welcoming, sweet and fast waiters, plenty of space between the tables, with really likeable-looking people having their meals, and a...
review_full: I know I may get brickbats for this review, but you can only judge by your own experience, and this was ours. Los Porfiados has welcoming, sweet and fast waiters, plenty of space between the tables, with really likeable-looking people having their meals, and a lovely atmosphere. My partner and I much enjoyed being there, but not the food. We both started with gazpacho, and that was fine. My partner then had quiche, and I something said on the menu to have tenderized beef, with red peppers, nuts and cheese. Whether it was the tenderization or its having been overcooked I don't know, but the meat had no taste whatever; nor had the cheese melted on top, and nobody seemed to have thought of doing anything about this by adding either herbs or spices or even salt of pepper, of which there was none on the table. I only ate it because I didn't want to spoil the evening for my partner by sending it back. For desert I had what we were told would be millefeuille filled with dulce de lece. This sounded a nice idea but proved to be dulce de lece spread between many layers of a thin pastry that had soaked up enough of the filing to turn into something like blotting paper. My partner had no desert, which to go on my experience seemed to have been a good choice. We paid the bill, thanked and shook hands with the waiters and wished them the best with the restaurant which one of them had told us had started only last autumn, and left. It was only then, as my partner asked me what my food had been like and I said all right without any enthusiasm, that she told me her quiche had been pretty poor, without any taste, and I owned up about my stuff. With so much else going for it, if only Los Porfiados found a chef who knew what he/she was doing - which shouldn't be too hard to judge from our experience of much better thought-out and cooked meals in four other Madrid restaurants on the Tripadvisor list (including one with a chef only 21!) - it could turn into something brilliant.

Prices are very reasonable as well.

review_preview: My parents and I were visiting from New York and came to Los Porfiados after reading many great reviews.  We hadn't realized that they don't actually start serving dinner until 8:30, so we wandered around the neighborhood for an hour.  It was definitely worth the...
review_full: My parents and I were visiting from New York and came to Los Porfiados after reading many great reviews. We hadn't realized that they don't actually start serving dinner until 8:30, so we wandered around the neighborhood for an hour. It was definitely worth the wait. Their menu offers an array of plates made with fresh ingredients. Between us, we tried empanadas, a burger, a curry chicken dish, and a salad. The servers were very friendly and the setting felt like home. The food cost half as much and was twice as good as any other restaurant in Madrid. Highly recommend this place!

Everything about it is good - the atmosphere is friendly and comfortable, the service is warm and genuine, and the food - oh - delightful! We had veal and pork, delicately prepared, succulent; followed by indulgent blueberry cheesecake and a layered dolce de leche dessert. All washed down with some smooth wines. Very reasonable prices. The whole experience makes me want to visit Madrid again to eat there!

title_review: Excellent Tapas and very friendly waiter!
review_preview: You are looking for extraordinary tasty, authentic Spanish food in a nice environment? So Casa Lucas is the best choice you can make. All the tapas we ordered were just delicious, very fresh and well presented. Here you can enjoy ‚ÄûRabo de toro‚Äú or ‚ÄûMadrid‚Äú...
review_full: You are looking for extraordinary tasty, authentic Spanish food in a nice environment? So Casa Lucas is the best choice you can make. All the tapas we ordered were just delicious, very fresh and well presented. Here you can enjoy ‚ÄûRabo de toro‚Äú or ‚ÄûMadrid‚Äú ‚Äì exquisite tapas you won‚Äôt find in the next best restaurant/tapas bar. The wine list covers nearly every Spanish wine region and you can be sure to find a good one to accompany your dishes. Casa Lucas offers a nice atmosphere. Clean, simple but not simplistic.  We were sitting on a table next to the bar. Although there was not plenty of space we didn‚Äôt feel cramped at all and we really enjoyed being there. This was not only because of the tasty tapas and the good wine, but also due to the very friendly and competent waiter. He helped us to assemble our dinner and made us feel very comfortable. We strongly recommend spending time at Casa Lucas. Next time in Madrid, we won‚Äôt miss coming back.

We normally go for dinner but they also do lunch. I love the deco here. My super favorite dish is the milanesa, absolutely superb. My boyfriend loves the fish and chips too...and everything else is very tasty and fresh...pizzas, quiche, salads... The wine list is a bit short but good enough...for red Epica ( good Ribera deal Duero) and for white El Perro Verde, excellent Verdejo. If you are thinking where to dine in Madrid, you know where to go. And the prices are sooo good too!

Table in sitting area was galvanised tin truck etc. Thanks to other reviewers who brought to our attention !

title_review: Lovely cosy setting, attentive staff and good food
review_preview: Firstly, I feel I should address some of the other comments about the neighbourhood this restaurant is located in. Yes, the area would probably be best described as 'up and coming' in English parlance but the level of intimidation mentioned by other reviewers is a...
review_full: Firstly, I feel I should address some of the other comments about the neighbourhood this restaurant is located in. Yes, the area would probably be best described as 'up and coming' in English parlance but the level of intimidation mentioned by other reviewers is a gross over exaggeration in my opinion. It reminded me of Istanbul with groups congregating in the streets but we were left totally to our own devices, none of the groups approached us in any way or made us feel uneasy. They were simply socialising and not waiting to pounce on vulnerable tourists as I've seen some other reviewers suggest. Onto the restaurant itself, after a little difficulty finding it. The venue is very nicely designed but retains a certain intimacy as it only has around ten tables of varying sizes. Upon arrival, we were greeted by a very genial waiter who really appreciated our attempts at Spanish while politely correcting and assisting in English where this fell down. The menu itself is very quaintly detailed on a series of cards bound with a key ring with no English tourist translations to be had so you know the focus will be on authentic good food. I had their local take on a hamburger with wonderful fillings and a hand formed burger of medium-rare beef and my wife had a red cabbage and goats cheese quiche. Her quiche was nice but could have done with more goats cheese to counter the slightly overbearing amount of red cabbage. The mains were followed by a delightful selection of desserts from the counter which were all very well made and very tasty. All food is served on beautiful crockery. We found the food and drink to be very good value and the service was great with a host who really appreciated our attempts at the local dialect and engaged with us to improve our knowledge of the language which benefitted us later in the trip.

review_preview: After scanning the reviews, this place looked promising, we waited until after 9:15 so we wouldn't be the "early ones".. Right off the bat, the service was perfunctory - if not outright sullen.  When we were asked if we wished for water, we stressed "agua...
review_full: After scanning the reviews, this place looked promising, we waited until after 9:15 so we wouldn't be the "early ones".. Right off the bat, the service was perfunctory - if not outright sullen. When we were asked if we wished for water, we stressed "agua ordinario" - "tap water". The waiter responded "tap water?" and we replied "yes". Of course, he then brought an open bottle of bottled water, which we sent back, and got the agua del grifo - okay, maybe just a communication error . They then place bread on our plate without asking - of course another 3 Euro charge - no big deal, but if you intend to charge, you should ask first. I think that asking for tap water set the waiter's foul mood - no amount of cajoling or friendliness seemed to help.  When the paella arrived (minimum order two people) it looked very good - and the rice itself was quite good. The problem was that the seafood - it was supposed to be seafood paella - was so minimal that there was virtually nothing but good tasting rice and shells - no seafood contained within the shells of the various crustaceans. No tools... Is this how seafood paella is supposed to be? We were both very disappointed. Good-tasting rice for two people and a small salad should not cost over 60 Euros. (the seafood paella was only available a la carte for two.) That was after we had to correct the bill that was first presented to us. Initially the bill was even higher - they tried to charge us 5.50 Euro (!?) for the bottle of water that we had not ordered - and seemed not in the least surprised when we asked not to be charged for it - I don't particularly care for people trying to scam me.  In short - very good tasting rice - lousy seafood paella (as a finished dish beyond the rice), AWFUL service - and dishonest billing. This is the only place we dined in Madrid where where we had a bad experience. There are MANY, MANY better places in Madrid.

review_preview: This restaurant has a fantastic "menu del d√≠a" ‚Ä¶ I highly recommend the chicken with vegetables if you go this route.I went there with my girlfriend in October and then again with my parents in December. With my girlfriend we got the menu because...
review_full: This restaurant has a fantastic "menu del d√≠a" ‚Ä¶ I highly recommend the chicken with vegetables if you go this route. I went there with my girlfriend in October and then again with my parents in December.  With my girlfriend we got the menu because it was a good deal. We were very satisfied with all dishes.  With my parents, I got the menu and they got a vegetable paella which was heavenly. My dad declared that it was the best paella he had tasted and I would have to agree. It is not like other paella's you find, it is richer in flavor and unique.  The decor is very nice inside and the seating area is large. You will see Spanish people eating here as well, not just tourists.

review_preview: In a single word, this restaurant is Grand.The top factor I consider when reviewing a restaurant is ‚Äúdid I get my money‚Äôs worth?‚Äù With our first visit to Zalacain, we left with no doubts about it being worth every Euro. Why? From my first...
review_full: In a single word, this restaurant is Grand. The top factor I consider when reviewing a restaurant is ‚Äúdid I get my money‚Äôs worth?‚Äù With our first visit to Zalacain, we left with no doubts about it being worth every Euro. Why?   From my first phone call to book a table to the parting good-by after midnight, everything seen, heard, done and swallowed was perfect. And it‚Äôs not just a matter of value for the money.  Ambiance, quality, demonstrated experience, qualified service staff, fine cellar, top d√©cor and much more add up to the score of 10+++. If I had to compare Zalacain to other properties I know well, I would put it in the class with Munich's Tantris. Elegant, polished, top drawer without being pretentious. If there was any flaw to the evening it was in that we probably drank too much, but perfectly matched wines with the ‚ÄúTo Know‚Äù menu couldn‚Äôt be passed up and the service, timing of each course and presentation were exceeded only by the masterpieces of perfection that kept coming from kitchen to our table. If you want top class in every respect of a contemporary, yet classic restaurant in Madrid, this is not to be missed. Zalacain is a short cab ride to the north of Madrid and if you go, take the name and address with you for your taxi driver. Some may not know this well-kept secret. Arrive early (2100 hrs) and expect a full course meal to last at least 2.5-3 hours.  Dress for the occasion. A suit, or at least jacket and tie for the men is required, (thank God), and if you have thoughts about showing up a la typical American casual, try Burger King in the city instead. Our tab was in the range of 300 Euros and worth twice that. We‚Äôll go again, even if we just fly to Madrid for a superb dinner!!! Note: In spite of a fine, detailed web site, I found no way to book with Zalacain on line and, thanks to a friend, made our reservation by telephone from Barcelona.

title_review: Perfect, down-to-earth Tapas place in La Latina
review_preview: Casa Lucas serves delicious classic Spanish tapas in an intimate down-to-earth setting. After ordering drinks, we were served complementary bread with delectable salami pieces. We ordered the cheesy, mixed croquettes with ham and mushrooms which were great. We tried the tomato and cheese salad, expecting...
review_full: Casa Lucas serves delicious classic Spanish tapas in an intimate down-to-earth setting. After ordering drinks, we were served complementary bread with delectable salami pieces. We ordered the cheesy, mixed croquettes with ham and mushrooms which were great. We tried the tomato and cheese salad, expecting an Italian Capresa salad but the drier, flakier Spanish sheep cheese, the unique tomatoes and the oregano/basil flavors made it something completely different. Tasty! For the finale we ordered the calamari with squid sauce on the side. Very good! The prices service was warm and friendly, much like most of Spain...Highly recommended!

title_review: Great food in a very friendly atmosphere
review_preview: We dined at Casa Lucas with friends, who had already dined at the restaurant a few times earlier in the week. Upon entering, our friends were immediately recognized and given a warm greeting, which was extended to us, by the owner, bartender and server. This...
review_full: We dined at Casa Lucas with friends, who had already dined at the restaurant a few times earlier in the week. Upon entering, our friends were immediately recognized and given a warm greeting, which was extended to us, by the owner, bartender and server. This open, welcoming attitude carried on throughout the meal, as one of the three consistently stopped to ensure that everything was to our liking. Based on our friend‚Äôs recommendation, I had the calamari. This was unlike any calamari dish that I had seen. The squid was cut into approx. 1.5 inch (4 cm) wide strips, which were bound together with a piece of bacon and then deep fried. It was served with garlic aioli and emulsified squid ink. When the food arrived, the waiter asked if I would like for him to prepare it for me. He proceeded to cut the squid and bacon into bit-sized pieces. He then mixed the squid ink and garlic aioli and tossed it all together. The mixed dish looked very unappetizing, but tasted amazing. Extremely friendly environment, great service with fantastic food at reasonable prices. I highly recommend Casa Lucas.

Even on a Tuesday the place was crowded with locals already at 9.15 pm which is very early for Madrilenos. We got a reservation which then got a bit delayed, but the extremely friendly and efficient staff made up for it with small servings on the house with our canas while we were waiting to get seated. At the table we ordered five raciones ranging from squid in ink sauce to salads and canolis and they came gradually and with more canas as they should. At all times we were served with great attention and care despite that the two owners were extremely busy. It was a joyful experience - the perfect atmosphere and marvelous food of a modern Spanish cuisine made it a memorable evening with great fun around the table. We ended up paying less than 20 euros per person - amazing.

review_preview: With myriads of tapas bars in Madrid, we took a bet and chose this joint based on the praises from tripadvisor. This time the reviews was spot on and boy we were ecstatic with this decision on our last night in Madrid.The menu was...
review_full: With myriads of tapas bars in Madrid, we took a bet and chose this joint based on the praises from tripadvisor. This time the reviews was spot on and boy we were ecstatic with this decision on our last night in Madrid. The menu was one pager grouped by its portions. We had the Manchos, Calamari with squid's ink mousse and Cannelloni (Black pasta stuffed with seafood and curry, with cream sauce). They were cooked and presented with perfection. The combination was ingenious, and every bite tingled our palates. The bill came up to 40 euros which include two glasses of sangrias. Not too pricey but not exactly the best of value. Nevertheless with this quality, this is by far one of the best eatery place in Madrid.

review_preview: This was one of my favorite tapas places in Madrid.  Brightly lit and filled with what looked like just a few tables and a bar, this quaint little bar delivered some of the most flavorful and inventive tapas we had in Madrid.  Most of the...
review_full: This was one of my favorite tapas places in Madrid. Brightly lit and filled with what looked like just a few tables and a bar, this quaint little bar delivered some of the most flavorful and inventive tapas we had in Madrid. Most of the other tapas places we passed by served more traditional dishes, but the options here were unique and contemporary. We tried two things here that were both absolutely amazing: a pintxo of soy/sesame sauce-marinated chicken with corn mousse and a racione of squid ink cannelloni filled with curried vegetables. So very delicious that I wish we had stayed here all night and kept going down the chalkboard menu.

review_preview: I was last here 22 years ago. Very little has changed in the atmosphere and formality of the restaurant.  The service is superb. This is really a dining experience. The prices are high but the portions are also substantial. The dishes, at least what we...
review_full: I was last here 22 years ago. Very little has changed in the atmosphere and formality of the restaurant. The service is superb. This is really a dining experience. The prices are high but the portions are also substantial. The dishes, at least what we ordered, were not as inventive or tasty as other similarly priced and rated restaurants we have been to on other cities. However the experience is worth the visit. The steak with garlic was delicious and perfectly prepared. The sole with white asparagus sauce and mustard too drenched with the sauce and not subtle. The gazpacho was only average, and was the flavor of the shrimp in the shrimp and avocado salad was bland, although the dressing was very good. The cava by the glass; excellent.

review_preview: We chose Zalacain as our one upscale restaurant experience during a week-long vacation in Spain and were very disappointed. I had warned the restaurant that one member of our party was a vegetarian and this information seems to have been lost. We were served amuse-bouches...
review_full: We chose Zalacain as our one upscale restaurant experience during a week-long vacation in Spain and were very disappointed. I had warned the restaurant that one member of our party was a vegetarian and this information seems to have been lost. We were served amuse-bouches containing ham, and even the vegetable stew on the menu (pretty much the sole vegetarian option) tasted like it was cooked in chicken stock. The member of our party who had fish, however, was fairly happy. All in all, an okay bet for carnivores and pescetarians but a place to avoid if you have any dietary restrictions. Certainly not a world-class dining experience.

title_review: Zalacain is an exquisite gastronomical experience, although expensive.
review_preview: Zalacain is an exquisite, albeit quite expensive, restaurant. My husband and I had experienced its gastronomic delights on a trip to Madrid about 10 years ago. Our recent visit was no less glorious. The decor and table appointments are elegant, and the service is gracious...
review_full: Zalacain is an exquisite, albeit quite expensive, restaurant. My husband and I had experienced its gastronomic delights on a trip to Madrid about 10 years ago. Our recent visit was no less glorious. The decor and table appointments are elegant, and the service is gracious without being overbearing. We usually select dishes that we will share, and the monk fish with shrimp as well as the roast rack of lamb selected were each a visual and gourmet delight. There is a jacket and tie dress code, but that's no surprise in such a splendid restaurant.

title_review: Great wines (by the glass) and tasty food
review_preview: Went here on a Friday night and managed to get two spaces at the bar as soon as we walked in. Even if it looks busy I would recommend hanging about a bit to see if spaces become available as the turn around seems very...
review_full: Went here on a Friday night and managed to get two spaces at the bar as soon as we walked in. Even if it looks busy I would recommend hanging about a bit to see if spaces become available as the turn around seems very fast in some cases. The two of us ended up having 1 glass of white and 2 glasses of red wine each to wash down the incredibly tasty pulpo with garlic and squid ink and the oxtail. As the food was so tasty, we had to try one tapa and went with the juicy pork on melt in the mouth onions and bread. My partner had a sherry in the end and we both were given a sweet wine. All that for less than 70 EUR in a very friendly atmosphere. Might have to come back to Madrid just to eat and drink there again!

review_preview: We decided to go here based on TripAdvisor reviews and the fact that this was also returned on a Google search for "best tapas bars Madrid"! We were not disappointed. We went at 3 pm for a late lunch and the food was incredible. We...
review_full: We decided to go here based on TripAdvisor reviews and the fact that this was also returned on a Google search for "best tapas bars Madrid"! We were not disappointed. We went at 3 pm for a late lunch and the food was incredible. We shared the cannelloni which you absolutely must try. It was so good we are going back for dinner tonight! Tip: This tapas bar shuts at 4 pm and re-opens at 8 pm until 2 am. It's small but I was told by the waiter you don't need a reservation if you go around 8 pm. Drinks are about 3 euros per glass of wine / beer, and snacks are 5 euros each. The larger portions are 15 to 20 euros each so a bit more expensive than other tapas bars in Madrid, but definitely worth it. Super friendly waiter / barman who speaks English.

title_review: So and so - Nella media niente di speciale
review_preview: We went here because of the enthusiastic opinions we read on TA: maybe it's because we're italian but we didn't find this place so good. The ambient is characteristic, the owner is very friendly but the food is average and the prices not so cheap....
review_full: We went here because of the enthusiastic opinions we read on TA: maybe it's because we're italian but we didn't find this place so good. The ambient is characteristic, the owner is very friendly but the food is average and the prices not so cheap. We took pintxos (good ones) and as main courses octopus (too much potatoes inside) and fried squid (average). Two very lite beers and two cups of white wine for ‚Ç¨ 45! My opinion: if you're round here it's ok but don't come on purpose only for eating here. Normally in Madrid you can have lunch for half price at the same quality. #4 on TripAdvisor seems to me a little bit over rated. Ci siamo venuti perch√© avevamo letto delle ottime recensioni: sar√† perch√© siamo italiani, sar√† perch√© conosciamo bene la Spagna ma il posto non ci √® affatto sembrato eccezionale. title_review: Delicious home-made food, excellent attention, and great value. The total package
review_preview: This has been my favorite eatery since I arrived in Madrid. It quickly turned into my place of choice for bringing visiting family members and friends. If you pass through the Mercado de Chamartin during working hours you will be hard pressed to locate the...
review_full: This has been my favorite eatery since I arrived in Madrid. It quickly turned into my place of choice for bringing visiting family members and friends. If you pass through the Mercado de Chamartin during working hours you will be hard pressed to locate the restaurant, but once everyone turns in for their siesta at 2pm, out come the tables and hungry people start arriving just in time for the staff to greet them like family. They have a variety of fresh pasta that you can combine with any of their sauces or you can opt for the daily menu, which includes an appetizer, first and second course, dessert and beverage. Lunch for two is around 20 to 25 Euros which, taking into account the high quality of the food, is astonishingly good value. I have seen food that is x10 worse go for double that price. Attention is first rate, this guys really know how to treat a customer so that they come back. Ingredients are fresh, the food is inspired, desserts are amazing (looking at you, Cannoli and Tiramisu) and you can even buy their pasta,sauces and lasagna to eat at home. Do yourself a favor and reserve a table (highly recommended since they can only field about 8-10 tables plus stools at the bar) and try their no-pretense food that will leave you, and your wallet, feeling good afterwards.

review_preview: This was our 4th visit to Madrid and each time we have been we have wanted to eat here, this year we booked a table and looked forward to a lovely meal.On arrival the restaurant was busy, we were taken to our table and...
review_full: This was our 4th visit to Madrid and each time we have been we have wanted to eat here, this year we booked a table and looked forward to a lovely meal. On arrival the restaurant was busy, we were taken to our table and given the menus. Within a couple of minutes we were asked for our order but hadn't even had time to look at all the choices. Bread and a salmon and cream cheese dip were brought to us and it was delicious, I could have eaten more of the dip.  We ordered a bottle of red wine a glass of Rose and water for the table.  For starters I had whitebait and my partner had squid, mine arrived and looked like a bowl of batter bits with a fried egg on top. There was no taste of fish whatsoever and it just felt like a very greasy bowl of food. My partners starter was no better, another bowl of batter, I am not even sure his was squid. As soon as I put my cutlery down, the waiting staff were on one side to remove the plates and on the other side another member of staff had our mains. We felt incredibly rushed. We both ordered the cod with potatoe rosti, these were also disappointing. The rosti was soggy and the cod had no taste to it whatsoever, I had to add salt and pepper to give it any taste. Twice I placed my cutlery down during the meal to chat and on both occasions someone came over to take my plate.  We finished our second course and I checked the time, we had been in the restaurant for 40 minutes. The bottle of wine still had over half left in it.  The waiter came over and asked if we had enjoyed our meal and when we said no, he said sorry and walked away. We didn't complain mainly due to the language barrier but also because we didn't want to attract attention. I was disheartened that when we said no we hadn't enjoyed our meal no one came over to ask us why, it really felt like they didn't care and wanted people in and out as quickly as possible. If we had wanted fried food from a fast food chain then we would have found one, what we wanted was some lovely fish dishes in an authentic restaurant.  This was a disappointment and we would not visit or recommend this place to others.

review_full: Our first vacation in Spain, like most tourists we asked our guide for a restaurant recommendation to try some Paella. She didn‚Äôt even hesitate. ‚Äú Marina Ventura is only a ten minute walk and you will love it. Better make reservations ‚Äú. So we asked our hotel clerk and clearly this wasn‚Äôt the first time for her. She too said we will love it. Now we couldn‚Äôt wait. There are lots of restaurants in the old historic part of Madrid and we went to a few of them but we all agreed this was our favourite. Very nice and modern decor, four people attending to us, they helped us select our wine and meals even to the point of telling us we ordered too much and to remove some items. Of course they were right. The portions were great and we still didn‚Äôt finish it all. Sunday night and the place was full, the staff were running around but all was good, you could still carry on a conversation and the staff was always there to make sure all was good. For a popular place, the food was very good, and a lot more reasonably priced than we expected. Would definitely recommend.

Free and huge appetiser of aubergine and parmesan antipasto2. Burrata caprese (buffalo Mozzerella caprese with...
review_full: Beautiful, tasty little Italian in the Mercado! We sat in the small 3-bar-tabled dining area and, based on enthusiastic recommendation by the owner, we had (here's a list): 1. Free and huge appetiser of aubergine and parmesan antipasto 2. Burrata caprese (buffalo Mozzerella caprese with green pesto) 3. Truffle ravioli without sauce - only olive oil and fresh parmesan sprinkled on top  4. A tiramisu  5. Focaccia bread and a large glass of white wine each The food was all incredible and plenty between us - we're glad we shared! And by far the best Italian meal we've had in Madrid so far. The bill came to ‚Ç¨26 exactly which felt very reasonable for the quality of food and service we received. The owners are a husband and wife duo. He's Spanish and speaks fluent English. He told us that he learned to cook under Heston Blumental in the UK for four years, then worked in one of the UK's top restaurants for a few more. Very interesting. His wife is Italian and runs the kitchen with 2 others. I hope you get the chance to visit :)

Well cooked with an enormous quantity of fresh seafood. However, our appetizers were also excellent, including...
review_full: We went to this restaurant specifically for their paella, as it was highly rated on several different websites. We had paella de mariscos, and, as advertised, it was delightful. Well cooked with an enormous quantity of fresh seafood. However, our appetizers were also excellent, including a rather unusual smoked duck salad. We had a bottle of superb Priorat wine with the meal, and it couldn't have been better. Service was fast, professional, and delivered with a smile in either English or Spanish, as preferred. The interior of the restaurant is attractive and chairs and tables comfortable. In a city full of delightful dining experiences this one stands out.

review_full: I visited Zalacain on my first trip to Madrid; and what a superb dinner experience!  Absolutely delicious food - difficult to chose from the menu due to too many tempting dishes:-). I decided to go for the Spanish Jambon (not to miss), Foie Gras, oven roasted Lobster on vegetables - and in addition hereto small tapas as appetizers, and sweets with the coffeee/tea were served. The sommelier recommended a white Rioja - and the choice couldn't be more perfect.  It was not only a good experience with the food - also the service was excellent.  Thank you for a memorable experience - I will definitely come back, should I ever come to Madrid again.

review_preview: This is a lovely find, slightly off the main tourist track of central Madrid, and one of the loveliest meals we had during our stay! The head chef had many hilarious stories and kindly whipped us up some homemade pasta made with pear and cheese!...
review_full: This is a lovely find, slightly off the main tourist track of central Madrid, and one of the loveliest meals we had during our stay! The head chef had many hilarious stories and kindly whipped us up some homemade pasta made with pear and cheese! Absolutely delicious. The wine, homemade bread, yummy starter salads and fresh tiramisu added to the splendid menu. Even if you don't fancy taking a sit down meal here, you should definitely swing by during the day to pick up some delicious bites to eat and take home some bottles of wine! You won't regret it and it's certainly a lovely break from the tapas! Gracias! : )

title_review: Still delicious paella on our second visit 13 years later
review_preview: When we were in Madrid in 2006, this place was recommended to us at our hotel, and we really enjoyed our lunch (paella) that day. Talking to our server that day, she told us that the secret to a good paella is the caldo (stock)....
review_full: When we were in Madrid in 2006, this place was recommended to us at our hotel, and we really enjoyed our lunch (paella) that day. Talking to our server that day, she told us that the secret to a good paella is the caldo (stock). We had a rough idea of the location when we returned a few weeks ago for lunch, but it looked different. Our server this time told us that they had undergone a renovation a few years ago. We ordered the paella off the menu of the day, and it included a beverage and dessert too. While the paella seemed drier this time (I remember being surprised at its moistness the first time years ago because it was different from the other types of Spanish rice from different countries which we both enjoy), it was still delicious. The secret must be in the caldo!

review_preview: Marina Ventura is very close to our hotel so before we visited Spain I looked at Trip Advisor reviews of nearby restaurants. Last night we went to Marina Ventura and enjoyed it so much we went again tonight for our final dinner in Madrid. Both...
review_full: Marina Ventura is very close to our hotel so before we visited Spain I looked at Trip Advisor reviews of nearby restaurants. Last night we went to Marina Ventura and enjoyed it so much we went again tonight for our final dinner in Madrid. Both times we had rice with squid, mussels, shrimp, pork and chicken‚Äîdelicious! Everything is prepared to order so it takes about 25 minutes to be served. In the meantime we had an appetizer of fried baby squid and also there was a delicious dip with little crackers. Tonight we shared a yummy dessert of apple crisp with vanilla ice cream and toffe. We also shared a pitcher of Sangria the first night. The food was hot and tasty, and the service really good. Tonight before we left the waitress brought us a complimentary cordial. We really enjoyed our two dinners at Marina Ventura and I highly recommend it!
